nodes.bodyText: I don't understand this comment...
I will clarify the comment :)

Is it worth thinking about using Antlr for parsing the directive content? e.g. another syntax file that defines the format of directives?
May make it easier to extend in the future, without having to write complex regex and parsing code.
this could definitely be worth it so we can specify different types of directives, for now I think it's a little overkill - I'll explore this in a future PR

What's this for?
If this is just so that from can return something, why not make from return Optional<Type>?
May be worth adding Java docs to each of these types with an explanation of what they do and how they should be used... or better yet... start compiling .md files for format of tests.  We have this for QTT. Need it for YATT too.

I prefer having an UNKNOWN over an optional so that we don't always have to check if present and then just have a switch statement on the enum anyway.
I'll add javadoc, and then when the code is somewhat ready for public consumption I'll add all the formal docs. This push was really to get it in a state where I can use it for query upgrades (and after that this will likely be a main project for me anyway, so I'll have dedicated time on it)

Sure, no worries if you feel strongly about it.
I only raise it as I've seen such patterns before, where the enum includes an 'UNKNOWN' or 'error' value. It can result in the code becoming littered with switch statements that contain the UNKNOWN case, which then throw an exception, even though it can never be hit, because some earlier check has already handled it.
Is there any reason why you can't just throw an exception with the location saying 'unknown directive'?

My instinct was to have it just ignore unknown directives and move on (as if it were another comment) so that tests can be parsed in previous versions where the directives may not exist. I'm happy also throwing the exception here in parse-time if we don't want that behavior

nodes.bodyText: not easy to implement it as an Iterable given the nature of TokenStreams and Lexers

Sure is easy. Just move all that into the iterator!  the Iterable then just storers the data to be parsed, and the iterator does the parsing and iterating.
Though I agree it would be weird to have it as Iterable.
BTW, why not just have it parse every line and return it as a List, then iterate through the list?   What's the benefit of it parsing as you go?

Sure is easy. Just move all that into the iterator! the Iterable then just storers the data to be parsed, and the iterator does the parsing and iterating.

Fair enough! Though that does feel weird :P

BTW, why not just have it parse every line and return it as a List, then iterate through the list? What's the benefit of it parsing as you go?

In my next PR I actually convert it to a list elsewhere. The reason I do it this way is so that I iterate until I find a --@test directive and then I start a new list. It just felt more natural to me than building a list then iterating the list to split it into tests. I could also build the list of lists here, but it turned out nicely with an iterator.
I don't really feel too strongly, so I'll keep this like this for now and if it causes headaches i'll make it return a list.

What happens if statements aren't separated by new lines?  Either directives or SQL statements?
I'm guessing for directives the second directive would just be in the text of the first, which is probably fine.  But can/does it support multiple SQL statements on a line, or indeed one statement spread across lines.  Tests needed :D
